title: Creatine Supplementation for Treating Symptoms of Depression: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

sections.abstract:
Nutraceuticals are increasingly of interest in nutritional psychiatry, where creatine has been 
investigated in several randomised trials for its effects on depressiv e symptoms. However, 
these findings have not yet been systematically synthesised. We conducted a systematic 
review to assess the effects of creatine supplementation on symptoms of depression. Four 
databases were searched up to February 202 5 for trials comp aring creatine with placebo in 
individuals with or without depression. Study selection, data extraction and risk of bias 
assessment (RoB 2) were conducted independently, and certainty of evidence was evaluated 
using GRADE. Random -effects meta -analyses with Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman 
adjustment including 11 trials (1,093 participants) found a standardised mean difference 
(SMD) of -0.34 (95% CI, -0.70 to -0.00; GRADE: very low quality of evidence), equivalent 
to 2.2 points on the 17-item Hamilton Depression Rating Scale, below the minimal important 
difference of 3.0 points. Confidence intervals include non -clinically important effects and 
heterogeneity was substantial (I² = 71.3%). While effects appeared larger in clinically -
depressed populations, subgroup an alyses and trim -and-fill adjustments indicated substantial 
bias favouring creatine.

CI 0.28 to 1 .88). Our findings suggest creatine may offer a small -to-moderate benefit for 
individuals with depression, but average effects were not clinically important and the true 
effect may be trivial or null. The evidence on which these results are based is very u ncertain. 
Larger, more rigorous randomised trials are required to draw definitive

sections.introduction:
Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) affects approximately 280 million people worldwide, 
standing as one of the leading causes of disability and nonfatal health loss. (1–3) Despite 
existing treatments, substantial unmet needs remain. Many individuals do not receive 
adequate therapy due to financial constraints, limited health literacy, or persistent stigma and 
misconceptions on mental health. Even for those who do receive clinical care, existing 
treatment options often fail to provide satisfactory symptom relief, carry notable side effects, 
and/or demand long-term commitment that some find difficult to maintain.(4–6) 
Creatine is widely used for enhancing sports performance, and has recently garnered attention 
as a potential therapeutic for brain health. (7,8) Creatine plays a pivotal role in brain energy 
homeostasis, and altered cerebral energy metabolism at a cellular level may be involved in 
the pathophysiology of depression. (9) Lower brain creatine levels are associated with both 
depressive symptoms and resistance to established treatments (10–12), and inverse associations 
were found between dietary creatine intake and prevalence of depression. (13) Oral creatine 
administration has been shown to increase brain phosphocreatine concentrations (14,15), 
providing a reasonable physiological basis for its clinical efficacy. 
Despite promising evidence, creatine is not currently recommended by major clinical 
guidelines (16), and previous systematic reviews of nutraceuticals for psychiatric disorders 
found limited evidence assessing its efficacy. (9,17,18) Several clinical trials are av ailable to 
determine the effects of creatine on symptoms of depression but these efforts have not yet 
been systematically synthesised. In this study, we present a first -in-field systematic review 
and meta-analysis of published and unpublished randomised tr ials to assess the efficacy of 
creatine supplementation on depression outcomes.
sections.methods:
This is a systematic review and meta -analysis investigating the effects of creatine 
supplementation to treat symptoms of depression. It was reported according to the Pr eferred 
Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta -Analysis (PRISMA) 2020 guidelines (19) 
and conducted according to the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of 
Interventions.(20) The protocol for this research was pre -registered in the Internation al 
Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42025649236). 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
Selection criteria 
Studies were eligible if they met the following criteria: 1) study design was a 
randomised controlled trial (RCT) ; 2) the intervention group received oral creatine; 3) the 
control group received placebo; 4) reported outcome data on depressive symptoms measured 
by a validated questionnaire. Only RCTs were included because high placebo responses, 
symptom fluctuation, and treatment‐selection processes in routine care can confou nd non -
randomised comparisons in depression research; RCTs minimise these biases, allowing the 
effect of creatine to be distinguished from non -specific influences and time trends, thus 
providing the most reliable estimates of intervention efficacy.(20) 
We included studies that used co -interventions (such as psychotherapy, 
antidepressants or exercise), as long as it was provided to both groups. We did not restrict our 
review to studies where participants had a diagnosis of depression or other mood disorders, as 
assessing the effects of creatine in the general population may also be relevant for decision -
making. No exclusions were made based on the type of creatine or dose. 
Search strategy 
Four databases were searched: MEDLINE, Web of Science, Embase and Coc hrane 
Library, from inception to February 17th, 2025. Full structure of the search strategy used in 
each database can be found in the Appendix ( Table S 2). Unpublished and grey literature 
were sought through clinical trial registries, conference proceedings , theses and dissertations. 
We also searched for studies in the bibliographies of potentially eligible trials upon full -text 
evaluation. 
Study selection and data extraction 
In stage 1 of the selection process, retrieved records were uploaded to Rayyan (21), 
where two reviewers (JL and AD) independently screened their titles and abstracts. In stage 
2, the full text of potentially eligible articles were evaluated before a final decision, also 
performed independently by JL and AD. Disagreements at both stages were resolved by
sections.discussion:
with a third author (IE). Data collection commenced on February 20th, 2025. Two 
reviewers (JL and AD) independently extracted study and sample characteristics, the data 
required for meta -analyses and funding/material provision i nformation to standardised 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
Microsoft Excel ® spreadsheets. Disagreements were resolved by inspecting and cross -
checking the original data source with a third reviewer (IE). 
Data analysis 
We performed pairwise frequentist meta -analyses using the meta package in R 
version 4.4.1. Continuous outcomes were calculated using an inverse -variance model and 
presented as standardised mean differences (SMD) in Hedge's g, as it tends to produce less 
biased results for studies with smaller samples and when sample s izes differ substantially 
between studies.(22) The restricted maximum likelihood (REML) variance estimator was used 
following published methodological guidance for continuous outcome data. (23) For 
dichotomous outcomes, we presented results using Odds ratio s (OR), calculated using an 
inverse-variance random-effects model with the Paule -Mandel estimator. As pre -specified in 
our protocol, random -effects were chosen as we expected significant between -study 
heterogeneity due to diverse patient populations, inter vention protocols and outcome 
measures. All analyses included a Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman adjustment, as it provides a 
better estimation of between study variance by accounting for small sample sizes. (24) 
Random-effects were prespecified as the primary model; however, in outcomes with very few 
trials or unstable/near-zero τ² (where HKSJ intervals can be extremely wide due to imprecise 
τ²), we additionally report a fixed -effect estimate as a sensitivity analysis, alongside the RE 
result. These fixed -effect estimates are provided solely to aid the interpretation under a 
common-effect assumption and should be regarded as supplementary and exploratory. 
We preferred to use intention -to-treat (ITT) data to minimise potential biases often 
associated with post -randomisation exclusions. Data from per -protocol analyses were 
extracted and utilised only if ITT data was not available. For depression symptomatology as a 
continuous variable, according to our pre -specified analysis plan, we only used post -
treatment values. All studies provided post -treatment data, but one study (Butchart et al., 
2022) reported 95% confidence intervals of post -treatment means instead of standard 
deviations (SD), which were transformed into SD. 
Where studies reported data for multiple arms ag ainst a single control group, we have 
split each study into multiple reports. This decision was based on chapter 16.5.4 of the 
Cochrane Handbook, which states that in order to overcome the issue of unit-of-analysis error 
it is possible to split the ‘shared ’ group (i.e., the control group receiving placebo) into two 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
groups with smaller sample size, and include two (reasonably independent) comparisons. 
Such a statistical maneuver was performed in only one study (Kondo 2016), which compared 
three creatine grou ps against a single placebo group. Nemets et al. (2013) and Alves et al. 
(2013) reported data for 4 groups, allowing for two completely independent comparisons of 
creatine vs. placebo in each study. 
Interpretation of findings 
We generated estimates using SMDs as studies measured depression with different 
instruments. However, presenting results in SD units has major limitations: clinicians and 
their patients are unlikely to be able to relate to this way of presenting results; if the 
variability or heteroge neity in the severity of patients’ condition varies between trials, the 
SDs will also vary; and if very homogenous populations are enrolled, SD units can give a 
misleading inflated impression of the magnitude of effect. (25) Thus, we have converted SMDs 
to the natural units of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS -17), with which many 
clinicians are familiarised and there is an established minimal clinically important difference 
(MCID) available. In accordance with the NICE guidelines, we chose a cutoff of 3 points to 
represent the minimal difference considered important to patients.(26,27) 
Risk of bias assessment 
Two reviewers (I.E. and J.L.) evaluated each trial using the revised Cochrane risk of 
bias tool for randomi sed trials version 2.0 (RoB 2) (28) according to the most recent 
guidance.(29) The tool comprises five domains, which were used to inform an overall risk of 
bias for each trial, based on (1) bias arising from the randomization process, (2) bias due to 
deviations from intended interventions, (3) bias due to missing outcome data; (4) bias due in 
the measurement of the outcome; and (5) bias in the selection of the reported result. Results 
of the RoB 2 informed domain 1 (within -study risk of bias) of our GRADE quality of 
evidence assessment. 
Prediction intervals 
Prediction intervals (PIs) were calculated and reported to show the expected effect 
range of a similar future study, in a different setting. In this sense, PIs provide a clinical 
meaningful measure, estimating where the true effect is exp ected for 95% of similar studies 
conducted in the future and allowing more informative inferences.(30) 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
Assessment of heterogeneity 
We used I 2 statistics to assess the proportion of variability in a pooled analysis that 
was explained by between -study heterogeneity, and to reflect the extent to which 95% 
confidence intervals from the different original research articles overlapped with each 
other.(31,32) For GRADE assessments, we interpreted I 2 statistics as recommended in the 
Cochrane Handbook: 1) 0% to 40% might not be important; 2) 30% to 60% may represent 
moderate heterogeneity; 3) 50% to 90% may represent substantial heterogeneity; 4) 75% to 
100% suggest considerable heterogeneity. 
In a random effects model, within -study measures of variability such as confidence 
intervals are not informative about the range of potential treatment effects given the 
heterogeneity between studies. (33) For this r eason, we also used PIs as an indicator of 
variation between studies, which can inform judgements regarding domain 2 (inconsistency) 
of our GRADE assessment in addition to traditional indicators.(34,35) 
Subgroup analyses and Meta-regression 
To assess for potential effect modifiers and explain statistical heterogeneity, we 
performed three pre -specified subgroup analyses: 1) studies that included populations 
diagnosed with affective disorders vs. studies including otherwise healthy individuals; 2) 
studies that provided creatine as an adjuvant therapy vs. studies that provided creatine as 
monotherapy; and 3) studies of higher vs. lower risk of bias. A p -value of <0.05 was 
considered statistically significant for subgroup interaction tests. 
We performed exploratory univariate meta -regression analyses using a mixed -effects 
model based on the following continuous variables as predictors: 1) treatment duration (in 
weeks); 2) daily creatine dose (in grams); and 3) baseline depression scores. As studies 
measured depression using different scales, we standardised baseline depression scores from 
0 to 100 in each study using the Proportion of Maximum Possible (POMP) method.(36) 
Sensitivity analyses 
Exclusion sensitivity analyses using the leave -one-out method were performed and 
displayed in forest plots to investigate the potential influence of individual studies on the 
overall results of the meta -analysis. We also performed a sensitivity analysis to determine if 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
our pre-specified analytical choice affec ted our primary findings by reanalysing it using the 
traditional DerSimonian and Laird model without the Hartung -Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman 
adjustment.(37) 
Assessment of publication bias 
Publication bias was investigated through visual inspection of a funnel plo t, in 
conjunction with statistical tests using Egger's regression. (38,39) In order to adjust for potential 
small-study effects and attain a corrected effect estimate, we used the Duval & Tweedie trim 
and fill method.(40) 
Quality of evidence assessment 
The quality of evidence was assessed using the Grading of Recommendations 
Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE) system. (41) Each outcome was initially 
determined as 'high quality of evidence’, which could be downgraded to ‘moderate’, ‘low’ or 
‘very lo w’ based on the five following domains: 1) within -study risk of bias; 2) 
inconsistency; 3) imprecision; 4) indirect evidence and 5) publication bias. The interpretation 
of each outcome was based on GRADE guidelines 26, which presented informative 
statements to communicate the findings of systematic reviews of interventions.(42) 
RESULTS 
Study selection 
A total of 558 records were identified in our initial search, of which 353 were 
screened after excluding duplicate records. We subsequently examined the full -text of 34 
potentially eligible studies, of which 11 were included in our systematic review: 9 studies 
from indexed journals (43–51) and 2 unpublished studies (Kious, 2024; Renshaw, 2024) found 
on ClinicalTrials.gov. The selection process is presented in Figure 1. A list of all excluded 
studies is presented in the Appendix. 
Characteristics of the included studies 
Eleven studies (with 2,117 randomised individuals) were included. Most trials were 
small, with sample sizes ranging from 9 to 100, with the exception of Kieburtz et al., a 
multicenter trial that randomised 1741 participants. Three studies explicitly self -identified as 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
pilot trials (Nemets, 2013; Toniolo, 2017; Kious, 2024; Sherpa, 2025). Trials were conducted 
in India (Sherpa, 2025), South Korea (Lyoo, 2012), Israel (Nemets, 2013), Canada (Butchart, 
2022), United States of America (Kieburtz, 2015; Kondo, 2016; Brooks, 2023; Kious, 2024; 
Renshaw, 2024) and Brazil (Alves, 2013; Toniolo, 2017). 
All studies were of parallel-group design comparing creatine to placebo. Creatine was 
always offered via oral administration, with a median daily dose of 5 grams across studies. 
Only two trials prescribed creatine based on each subject's body weight (Bu tchart 2022; 
Brooks 2023). Two trials (Kondo, 2016; Nemets, 2013) had multiple intervention groups in 
order to test different doses. Kondo et al. tested three different doses in three groups (2 
grams, 4 grams and 10 grams) compared to a single placebo grou p, while Nemets et al. had 
two creatine groups (5 grams and 10 grams) and two placebo groups. Out of all studies, only 
Nemets et al. implemented a creatine dose titration regimen to reduce the risk of potential 
adverse events, starting with lower doses of creatine during the first week. In contrast, Kious 
et al. (2024) implemented a high -dose creatine load of 20g/day for 1 week, followed by 5 
weeks of usual doses (5g/day). In four studies, both groups received standard 
pharmacological treatment with antidep ressants (Lyoo, 2012; Nemets, 2013; Kondo, 2016; 
Toniolo, 2017); in one study, both groups received electroconvulsive therapy (Kious, 2024); 
in one study, both groups received psychotherapy (Sherpa, 2025); and in four studies no 
additional intervention for depression was offered (Alves, 2013; Kieburtz, 2015; Butchart, 
2022; Brooks, 2023). Treatment duration was generally short -term, ranging from 4 weeks 
(Nemets, 2013) to 10 weeks (Butchart, 2022). The exceptions were a 24 -week trial (Alves, 
2013) and a 5-year trial (Kieburtz, 2015). 
Six trials recruited individuals with a diagnosis of an affective disorder (either MDD 
or bipolar disorder) and the remaining recruited otherwise healthy individuals (Alves, 2013; 
Kieburtz, 2015; Butchart, 2022; Brooks, 2023); of these studies, one recruited a population 
with Parkinson's disease (Kieburtz, 2015). The average participant age in each trial ranged 
from 17.0 (Kondo, 2016) to 66.8 years old (Alves, 2013). All studies measured depressive 
symptomatology with appropriate scales, but their choices were highly variable (see Table 
1). The most common questionnaire was the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS). 
Funding and material provision 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
Among the included trials, most (7/11) reported public/academic or non-profit support 
and four did not report funding. One trial reported industry in -kind involvement (creatine 
supplied by AlzChem LLC). For most studies, the mode of creatine acquisition was not 
reported (one in -kind; one brand named without donation stated), and only thre e trials 
explicitly stated a funder role (two: no role; one: funder involved). Details by study are 
provided in the Appendix (Table S10). 
Risk of bias assessment 
Six studies were judged as overall high risk of bias and only one trial was judged as 
low risk of bias (Kieburtz, 2015). The most common concern was related to deviations from 
intended interventions, especially in trials providing co -interventions, where unbalanced 
treatments due to chance or unblinding could introduce bias. Measurement bias, parti cularly 
due to risk of unblinding, was also a common concern. Eight trials had a pre -registered 
protocol, of which only one presented a statistical analysis plan with pre -planned 
methodological decisions such as statistical models, how to deal with missing data and rules 
for excluding participants from their analyses (Kieburtz, 2015). The overall RoB assesment is 
presented in Figure 2 and detailed rationale for the judgement of each domain can be found 
in the Appendix (Table S7). 
Meta-analyses 
Primary outcome: Depressive symptomatology 
Eleven studies (1,093 participants) provided data on depressive symptoms and were 
included in the analysis. Creatine supplementation was associated with a greater reduction in 
depressive symptoms compared to placebo (SMD -0.34, 95% confidence interval -0.6831 to -
0.0004, but there was substantial between-study heterogeneity (Figure 3). Using the GRADE 
criteria, we judged the certainty of the evidence to be very low ( Table 2). Confidence 
intervals range between large to trivial effect sizes, suggesting uncertainty with regards to its 
clinical importance. In HDRS units, these results are compatible with a difference of -2.22 
(95% confidence interval, -4.4404 to -0.0028). 
 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
Secondary outcome: Remission of depression 
Based on two trials (70 participants), in a fixed -effect model meta-analysis, there was 
no evidence of a difference in response rates following creatine supplementation compared to 
placebo: OR 0.72 (95% confidence interval, 0.28 to 1.88). Confidence intervals include the 
possibility of large benefits and harms (72% reduction to 88% increase). Results from 
random-effects had excessively wide confidence intervals ( Appendix Figure S1 ). Using the 
GRADE criteria, the evidence was judged as very low certainty. 
Secondary outcome: Treatment response 
Based on three trials (187 participants), in a fixed -effect model meta-analysis, results 
were in favour of creatine supplementation compared to placebo: OR 3.65 (95% confidence 
interval, 1.76 to 7.56), but confidence intervals were very wide. Random -effects analysis 
revealed similar but more imprecise results (95% confidence interval, 0.99 to 13.15) 
(Appendix Figure S1). Using the GRADE criteria, the evidence was also judged as very low 
certainty. 
Secondary outcome: Quality of life 
Only one study reported quality of life (Kieburtz, 2015), measured by the EuroQOL 
instrument (EQ -5D). The mean baseline values were 0.8 (±0.2) for both groups. After 5 
years, both groups experienced a mean reduction of 0.1 points (representing a non -significant 
and clinically unimportant 0.005 mean difference between groups; 95%CI -0.03 to 0.04). 
Secondary outcome: Safety and adverse events 
Lyoo et al. (2012) reported similar frequencies of adverse events between groups 
(43.4% vs. 46.4%; p = 0.69). A mild elevati on of serum creatinine was observed exclusively 
in patients receiving creatine (0.79 vs. 0.67 mg/dL; p=0.03). Although not statistically 
significant, levels of liver enzymes (alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase) 
were also elevated in th e creatine group (23.5 vs. 20.0 units/L and 23.6 vs. 21.6 units/L, 
respectively). Kieburtz et al. (2015) reported an immediate increase in creatinine levels in the 
intervention group at the first post -baseline visit, which then stabilised, but no notable 
changes in other laboratory values over time. Kondo et al. (2016) reported that the adverse 
events most commonly affected the placebo group (4 out of 6 individuals), but no 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
information was reported regarding the creatine groups. Small mean differences in se rum 
creatinine were also observed (0.79 vs. 0.88 mg/dL in the control group and 10g/day creatine 
group, respectively). In Toniolo et al. 2017, the control group reported nearly double the 
amount of adverse events in the creatine group (17 vs. 33 events). T he authors reported that 
no patient exhibited serum blood urea nitrogen or creatinine levels above the upper limits of 
normality after 6 weeks of treatment, but data was not shown. Sherpa et al. (2025) reported a 
total of 127 adverse events (69 vs. 58 in the creatine and placebo groups, respectively). There 
were a total of 29 reports related to gastrointestinal adverse events (either constipation or 
diarrhea) in the creatine group vs. 17 in the placebo group. Abdominal pain was reported by 9 
participants in the creatine group vs. 1 in the placebo group. The proportion of other adverse 
events was generally similar between groups. No side effects or adverse events were reported 
in Nemets 2013, Butchart, 2022 or Brooks, 2023. 
Subgroup and meta-regression analyses 
Even though the number of studies and overall participants were low, we decided to 
present additional, exploratory analyses as they still may be somewhat informative. These 
analyses were conducted only for the primary outcome due to limited data avai lability. Forest 
plots are presented in the Appendix (Figure S4 to S6). 
Subgroup analysis based on risk of bias 
There was evidence of smaller effect sizes in depressive symptomatology in studies of 
lower risk of bias (5 trials, SMD: 0.06; 95%CI: -0.38 to 0.49) compared to studies of higher 
risk of bias (6 trials, SMD: -0.71; 95%CI: -1.10 to -0.32), with statistically significant 
subgroup differences (p = 0.0016). The heterogeneity within each subgroup was significantly 
reduced compared to the overall analys is (34.2% and 28.3% for the subgroup of higher and 
lower risk of bias, respectively). 
Subgroup analysis based on primary diagnosis of affective disorders 
Greater effect sizes were observed in the subset of studies including individuals with a 
diagnosis of an affective disorder (7 trials, SMD: -0.59; 95%CI: -0.95 to -0.22) compared to 
studies with otherwise healthy participants (4 trials, SMD: 0.04, 95%CI: -0.78 to 0.86), but 
the test for subgroup differences was not statistically significant (p = 0.0637 ). Confidence 
intervals for the subgroup with a primary diagnosis of affective disorders were still 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
compatible with both important and non -clinically important effects on the HDRS scale ( -
6.18 to -1.43). 
Subgroup analysis based on creatine as adjuvant vs. monotherapy 
Results for this subgroup analysis were identical to the subgroup analysis based on 
primary diagnosis of affective disorders, as the studies that provided creatine as an adjuvant 
therapy were exactly the same studies that included participants with affective disorders. 
Meta-regression analyses 
We found a statistically significant, inverse association between baseline depression 
scores (standardised from 0 to 100 across different scales) and a favourable effect for creatine 
(β = -0.0192; p = 0.01 32; R2 = 57.99%). Each 10-point increase in baseline depression score 
was associated with a 0.19 greater SMD in favour of creatine (equivalent to a 1.25 -point 
reduction in HDRS scale) for improving symptoms of depression. We found no clear 
evidence of an a ssociation between treatment effect and treatment duration (p = 0.3639) or 
daily creatine dose (p = 0.8257). 
Funnel plot 
The linear regression test of Egger was not statistically significant (p=0.2793), but the 
funnel was somewhat suggestive of an asymmetr y (Appendix Figure S2). We explored an 
additional analysis with the Duval & Tweedie Trim and Fill Method, which filled 6 effect 
sizes. The bias -corrected estimate was closer to the null (SMD: 0.01; 95%CI: -0.34 to 0.37; 
PI: -1.48 to 1.51), but remained highly heterogeneous (I2=80.8%). 
Sensitivity analyses 
We recalculated the results of our meta-analysis 15 times, each time leaving one study 
out (Appendix Figure S3). Effect sizes varied from -0.24 (when Lyoo, 2012 was omitted) to -
0.46 (when Alves 2013a was omitted). These results are consistent with mean reductions in 
HDRS-17 of 1.56 to 2.99 points. Only two analyses remained statistically significant (when 
removing Alves 2013a and Kieburtz 2015), but none of the 15 analyses resulted in clinically 
important effect estimates. Statistical heterogeneity ( I2) remained moderate to high in every 
analysis, ranging from 56% to 73%. Sensitivity analysis removing both unpublished studies 
(Kious 2024 and Renshaw 2024) were not statistically significant (SMD: -0.38; 95%CI: -0.78 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
to 0.02). Sensitivity analysis using the DerSimonian and Laird model without the Hartung -
Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman adjustment were also not statistically significant (SMD: -0.34; 95%CI: 
-0.70 to 0.01; PI: -1.51 to 0.82; I2: 71.3%). 
DISCUSSION 
Summary of the main results 
Our meta -analysis included a total of 11 trials involving 1,093 participants. The 
evidence shows statistically significant lower mean depression scores in creatine groups 
compared to placebo, with imprecise and hi ghly variable results across studies. Mean 
depressive symptomatology in creatine groups was approximately 2.2 points lower, 
representing a mean reduction below what is considered as clinically important in HDRS -17 
score. Confidence intervals were compatibl e with a clinically meaningful effect on the upper 
end, but also included an effect of negligible magnitude on the lower end. The certainty of the 
evidence was very low (see Certainty of the evidence). 
Meta-analysis of treatment response (2 trials) suggest ed no clear evidence of an 
effect, while in the meta-analysis of depression remission (3 trials) the average odds ratio was 
compatible with substantial benefit. However, these results were highly imprecise and mostly 
inconclusive due to limited data availability. The certainty of the evidence was also very low. 
Adverse events (AEs) were generally similar between intervention and placebo 
groups, occurred at an early phase and were reported to have improved without specific 
interventions. However, most studie s did not describe how AEs were identified and 
investigated in sufficient detail. Data reporting was widely variable, which precluded data 
pooling. In general, there was some evidence of an increased occurrence of gastrointestinal 
AEs and slightly increased serum creatinine associated with creatine supplementation. 
Rates of trial non‐completion (including dropouts, loss of follow -up, withdrawals and 
exclusions) were generally high across studies but fairly similar between intervention and 
placebo groups, wi th the exception of Toniolo et al., which excluded nearly 40% of the 
patients randomised to placebo vs. only 6% of those randomised to the creatine group. 
 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
Overall interpretation of the evidence 
The evidence for all outcomes is limited and highly heterogene ous, with findings that 
are imprecise and potentially biased. First, most available studies were very small, single -
center trials. Most of the data in the primary analysis derive from 6 trials at high risk of bias. 
The studies available were also highly he terogeneous: we found considerable differences in 
the type of participants involved, the type of standard care co -interventions, the duration of 
supplementation, and the range of different questionnaires used to measure depressive 
symptoms. Subgroup analyses were performed in order to reduce statistical heterogeneity and 
identify potential effect modifiers, but they were limited due to the small number of trials and 
several shared characteristics at study-level (e.g., studies investigating creatine as an ad juvant 
were also the same studies that recruited individuals with a diagnosis of an affective 
disorder). Corrected estimates addressing publication bias further suggest the results of our 
primary analysis are biased towards a benefit for creatine supplementation. 
Studies that did not provide other interventions in addition to creatine tended to result 
in smaller, non -significant effect sizes. This is consistent with a hypothesis that creatine per 
se may not provide an additional biological effect, but rathe r enhance the antidepressant 
effects of other therapies through a particular mechanism (e.g., enhancing reuptake inhibition 
of monoamines). However, even within the subgroup of trials assessing the effects of creatine 
as an augmentation agent, results were highly heterogeneous: two trials (Lyoo, 2012; Sherpa, 
2025) found very large effect sizes; two trials (Kondo, 2016; Toniolo, 2017) found a 
moderate effect size; two trials (Nemets, 2013; Renshaw, 2024) found small effect sizes; and 
one trial (Kious, 2024) found a null result. Trials that used creatine as the only treatment may 
also have found smaller effects due to other clinical differences (e.g., populations without 
affective disorders) or simply by chance. In addition, trials offering co -interventions may be 
at a greater risk of bias due to deviations from intended interventions in case of unblinding or 
due to small sample sizes, which will be discussed later on. It is currently not possible to 
determine if the effects of creatine were greater in some tr ials because 1) they were affected 
by biases related to unblinding and deviations from intended interventions; 2) creatine is 
actually effective only in individuals with affective disorders; 3) creatine is actually effective 
only when used as an adjunctive therapy that augments the efficacy of standard care 
treatments; or 4) other unknown or unmeasured variables (e.g., average baseline intake of 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
dietary creatine in each study). In general, until more studies with different characteristics 
and larger samples are conducted, it will be difficult to explain the heterogeneity of effects. 
Subgroup analyses showed larger effect sizes in studies at higher risk of bias 
compared to studies at lower risk of bias, with substantially smaller heterogeneity in each 
subgroup. These findings are consistent with meta -epidemiological evidence that shows 
higher risk of bias trials (especially of small sample sizes and single -center) tend to 
overestimate the effects of interventions. (52–54) However, it is important to acknowledge the 
limitations associated with small amounts of studies within each subgroup, and the fact that 
all included studies (including those judged as overall ‘some concerns’) shared similar 
limitations and risk of bias concerns, with the exception of Kieburtz et al. (2015). In addition, 
most trials at high risk of bias were also trials that studied individuals with affective 
disorders; thus, it is not possible to clearly determine whether these positive findings are due 
to bias, real effect, or a combination of both. 
Imprecise effect sizes were found for all results, especially for remission and 
treatment response, due to limited data availability. For our primary outcome, the mean 
difference was smaller than the MCID selected in our pre -specified protocol (3 po ints in the 
HDRS-17 scale). However, confidence intervals range from clinically important benefits to 
practically null effects. While this imprecision alone would not preclude recommendations in 
favour of creatine supplementation for many individuals, such uncertainty needs to be taken 
into consideration in conjunction with the currently unexplained heterogeneity, the overall 
within-study high risk of bias for most trials and small-study effects. 
Certainty of the evidence 
Using the GRADE criteria, the certa inty of the evidence for all outcomes was 
considered very low due to serious imprecision, serious within -study risk of bias and 
statistical heterogeneity that remained unexplained after subgroup analyses. We also found 
evidence to suggest that publication bias is present. Our judgements for each outcome can be 
found in the Summary of Findings (Table 2). 
Much of the evidence (53.5% weight) of our overall analysis derived from trials at 
high risk of bias, for which the certainty of the evidence was downgraded by two levels. The 
most critical limitation of the published clinical trials is the lack of adequate methods to 
control for and/or identify potentially unbalanced co -interventions. For ethical reasons, 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
studies on individuals with psychiatric diagnoses wil l typically receive creatine as an 
adjuvant (not monotherapy). Theoretically, when two groups receive the same treatments, it 
is possible to estimate the effect of an adjuvant intervention by prescribing it to one group 
while giving placebo to another. For instance, in Lyoo et al., as all patients received SSRIs, 
any difference between groups could be attributable to creatine. However, this inference is 
only acceptable as long as it is reasonable to assume that the SSRI treatment was equally safe 
and effective in both groups (i.e., they would have ended up with no differences in symptoms 
had they not received an additional treatment). For that to be true, patients in both groups 
should be equally tolerating and benefitting from the standard care, and receivi ng the same 
opportunities for successfully optimizing it. While randomisation can provide such isonomy 
in theory, it does not always work in practice. An example of this can be found in Toniolo 
2017, where 35 patients were randomised to two groups (17 vs. 18 patients). Soon after 
randomisation, three patients in the placebo group were lost, while three other patients in the 
placebo group changed medications in a way that deviated from the study protocol. In the 
creatine group, two patients presented worseni ng of their clinical depression and were 
excluded from the trial. Within 2 weeks, possibly due to chance, >22% of the study sample 
presented issues in an unbalanced manner, which may have biased the results in favour of the 
intervention. Many other issues in real life that affect depressive symptoms may not even be 
identified by (or reported to) the investigators, such as non-responsiveness or non-compliance 
to pharmacological/psychological treatments. Adequate randomisation creates groups with 
fairly simil ar prognosis at baseline, but unintended deviations and life events may ensue 
unpredictably during treatment period. Most of the currently available trials are very small, 
where participants in one group may end up having better prognosis simply due to cha nce, 
even after a perfectly randomised allocation. Future trials should be performed with larger 
sample sizes and consider implementing a run -in period before treatment allocation for 
accomodation/familiarisation with the standard care and study procedures , effectively 
reducing the risk of bias due to potential post-randomisation deviations. 
Another issue in creatine trials, particularly for subjective outcomes (such as 
depressive symptomatology), is the risk of unblinding during the treatment period. (55) 
Creatine, especially in high doses, may provoke mild and transient gastrointestinal side 
effects that could influence participants’ perception of what treatment is being received. If 
those assigned to creatine report minor side effects more frequently to ca regivers and/or 
outcome assessors, it may amplify biases related to deviations from intended interventions 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
and/or introduce bias in the measurement of the outcomes due to unblinding. Creatine 
supplementation may also lead to benign changes in biochemical t ests, especially serum 
creatinine levels. If patients, caregivers and/or outcome assessors are aware of the results 
from their biochemical tests, they may be able to tell apart patients receiving creatine and 
those receiving placebo, partially or totally breaking study blinding. Trialists can easily avoid 
this issue by blinding patients and study personnel to the results of biochemical tests; 
recommending patients to not take out -of-study blood tests; and have dedicated investigators 
(other than caregivers and outcome assessors) to handle biochemical data. Unfortunately, 
only one study included in this review has taken such precautions (Kieburtz, 2015). 
Our interpretation of the funnel plot was suggestive of an asymmetry, with small - to 
moderately-sized trials showing unfavourable (or less favourable) results potentially missing. 
Indeed, we found several records of clinical trials that were terminated, withdrawn or 
completed but not published (see Appendix Table S9) — which are typically associated with 
smaller treatment effects than published trials. (56) We explored an additional analysis to 
address publication bias with the trim and fill method, which provided results much 
consistent with a null effect (SMD: 0.01; 95%CI: -0.34 to 0.37), with confidence inter vals 
excluding clinically important differences in the HDRS scale. Overall, the trim and fill 
method indicated that the pooled SMD of -0.34 in our main analysis is probably 
overestimated due to small-study effects, and the real effect may be considerably s maller. Of 
note, although publication bias can lead to an asymmetrical funnel plot, there are also other 
causes that may produce similar patterns. (57) Differences in study populations, treatment 
duration, effectiveness of co -interventions and risk of bias between smaller vs. larger trials 
may have contributed to the observed asymmetry. It is also possible that funnel plot 
asymmetry simply occurs by chance, especially when there are few trials. For those reasons, 
we decided to take a conservative approach in our GRADE assessment and not downgrade 
the certainty in our primary outcome due to publication bias. However, the data unavailability 
that led to non -inclusion of several studies in our meta -analyses of secondary outcomes was 
considered as a clear reason for downgrading the certainty of evidence by at least one level. 
In summary, the evidence for all outcomes was considered as of very low certainty. 
Currently available body of evidence is composed of limited, predominantly small single -
center trials, within which there was substantial heterogeneity that remains unexplained even

after subgroup analyses. In addition, the fact that much of the contributing data derive from 
studies at high risk of bias suggests considerable need for caution. 
Potential biases in the review process 
 This is the first systematic review of creatine supplementation for treating symptoms 
of depression. We restricted our inclusion to randomised trials, thoroughly searched for 
unpublished studies (leading to the inclusion of two additio nal trials), provided formal 
quantitative syntheses of the available trials, performed plausible pre -specified subgroup 
analyses and presented transparent assessments of the certainty of the evidence and risk of 
bias. This review was strictly based on the most up -to-date Cochrane recommendations, 
followed a prespecified protocol and adhered to PRISMA guidelines for appropriate 
reporting. However, as with any systematic review, the findings of our study are as reliable as 
the extent of which the available ev idence contributes to our analyses. For secondary 
outcomes, only a very limited number of studies reported usable data. For our primary 
outcome, the available evidence is limited mainly due to the substantial influence of trials at 
high risk of bias and th e small number of studies. Outcome reporting did not always follow a 
pre-specified protocol registration and we relied heavily on available information within the 
manuscripts, meaning that biases due to selective reporting are possibly present. Our database 
searches were probably more likely to detect articles published in English and in peer -
reviewed, indexed journals. It is also possible our searches did not find closed -access articles 
that mentioned terms related to depressive symptoms only in the full t ext. In order to 
minimise these issues, we also performed searches in Google Scholar, gray literature 
databases such as OpenGrey and preprint servers, and avoided restricting our searches to title 
and abstract fields. Regarding our meta -analyses, studies w ere combined regardless of 
differences in study methodology and sample characteristics, as our review intended to 
answer a broad clinical question regarding the effects of creatine supplementation on 
improving symptoms of depression, which may have resulte d in statistical heterogeneity. We 
performed subgroup analyses to identify effect modifiers and provide explanations for 
heterogeneity; however, the paucity of data and co -existing study-level characteristics of key 
potential variables (e.g., subgroups of ‘diagnosis of mood disorder’ and ‘creatine as adjuvant 
therapy’ were composed of exactly the same studies) are challenging to interpret. Thus, 
caution is warranted in extrapolating from our subgroup analyses before more trials are 
available.

Agreements and disagreements with other studies or reviews 
There are many published non -systematic reviews on the potential effects of creatine 
supplementation for a number of clinical conditions and outcomes related to brain health, 
including cognitive processing, psyc hiatric disorders, dementia and traumatic brain 
injury.(10,58,59) In reviews where depression or its symptoms have been discussed, there were 
no attempts to implement systematic methods for study retrieval, study selection or a 
qualitative critical ap praisal through appropriate risk of bias tools and GRADE criteria. 
Previous reviews have only narratively explored the results of a few published trials, along 
with discussions of potential biological mechanisms through which the intervention could 
work, and generally concluded that the evidence is promising. In some cases, authors have 
even stated that “significant evidence” exists of its effectiveness for treatment -resistant 
depression.(60) In contrast, we present a more complete dataset of published and unpublished 
studies, and our analyses suggest that current evidence is largely consistent with non -
clinically important benefits, which are likely to be biased towards creatine therapy due to 
publication bias and within-study risk of bias. 
We were surprise d to not have found Kieburtz et al. (2015) cited (or thoroughly 
discussed) in many of the previously published reviews (12,61–63), considering it is a high -
quality, adequately -powered multicenter randomised trial. On the other hand, often -cited 
studies include single-arm, non-randomised, open-label small trials inherently at high risk of 
bias due to regression to the mean, spontaneous improvements and many other confounding 
factors.(64–66) Improvements in these single -arm trials may be completely attributab le to 
several factors associated with placebo response. (67) Importantly, Kieburtz et al. (2015) 
should be considered a design -model for future trials as it was the only study that 
implemented important methodological precautions that effectively preserved its internal 
validity, mainly related to its pre -specified statistical analysis plan and proper blinding to the 
results of biochemical tests; however, we have not found such key recommendation for future 
trials in previous reviews. Similarly, a multicenter trial creatine supplementation for 
Huntington disease including 553 participants (the CREST -E study) has also taken necessary 
(but rarely seen) precautions to maintain study blinding. (68) The authors instituted random 
suspensions to help mask suspensions due to true elevations caused by creatine metabolism 
and redacting potentially unblinding creatinine results, which were only visible to the clinical 
monitor. However, they recognize that AEs or other factors may have enabled some correct

guessing about tr eatment assignment, which could also explain the positive results in small 
trials included in our systematic review (especially those at high risk of bias). 
Implications for practice 
Previous clinical guidelines regarding the use of nutraceuticals and phyt oceuticals 
have not recommended creatine supplementation for adjunctive or monotherapy in MDD, 
mainly due to lack of convincing evidence of benefit. (16) In the WFSBP & CANMAT 
guidelines, only two trials were cited (Lyoo, 2012; Nemets, 2013), and no systema tic review 
of the literature was available. Many published non -systematic reviews have optimistically 
discussed potential benefits of creatine, usually over -emphasizing the results of positive 
randomised and non-randomised trials. Our analyses otherwise suggest that the available data 
is consistent with non-clinically beneficial (or null) effects, based on very uncertain evidence. 
The average treatment effect was found to be approximately 2.2 points on the HDRS -17 
scale, which can be undetectable by clinici ans(69) and lies below the assumed minimally 
clinically relevant effect. While confidence intervals do not exclude the possibility of an 
important benefit, there is considerable need for caution. Subgroup analyses based on risk of 
bias and trim-and-fill estimates have suggested that our main results are likely biased towards 
a positive finding of creatine supplementation, meaning that the true effect is probably 
smaller than observed. It is possible that creatine could be effective for specific subset of 
patients (e.g., as an adjunct therapy to individuals with a diagnosis of an affective disorder), 
but 5 out of the 7 trials addressing this population are at high risk of bias, and pooled results 
in this subgroup were highly heterogeneous and imprecise, sugge sting effects consistent with 
both clinically important and unimportant effects. Concerns regarding harms are low and it is 
unlikely that creatine would increase depressive symptoms; however, failure to seek for or 
adhere to conventional treatments can be unintended consequences of treatment with 
therapies such as creatine, representing a potentially dangerous opportunity cost. 
Implications for research 
More adequately -powered, well -designed studies are required to improve our 
assessment of the efficacy of creatine on depressive symptoms, and to understand the 
heterogeneity between study effects. It is important that future studies are performed in a way 
that overcomes limitations and biases in the available trials. Recently, guidelines on trial 
design, conduct and reporting in nutritional psychiatry have been published with key 
https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007114525105588
 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Accepted manuscript 
recommendations that should be incorporated in future studies of creatine for depression. (70) 
Our evaluation suggests a need for a more careful consideration regarding the isonomy of 
background treatments (e.g., antidepressants and/or psychotherapy) to reduce the risk of bias 
related to unbalanced co -interventions between groups typically associated with unblinding 
and small samples. Adding a run-in period prior to randomisation wi ll also help in this sense, 
with the added benefit of improving trial retention rates. Using a creatine dose titration, as 
seen in Nemets et al. (2013), may also be considered in order to minimise differences in side 
effects that could potentially subvert study blinding. Furthermore, concerns regarding 
blinding integrity related to the knowledge of biochemical tests can also be reduced by 
following the methodological approach of Kieburtz et al. (2015) and Hersch et al. (2017). 
Finally, studies should be per formed according to a detailed, pre -specified statistical analysis 
plan, publicly shared in online platforms such as ClinicalTrials.gov. More precise and 
complete reporting will also be extremely valuable for future meta -analyses, risk of bias 
assessments and overall interpretation of the evidence.
